content: I can't believe it. I actually got a response. One of the companies wants to schedule a technical interview.
Whoa, Ethan, that's fantastic news! Congratulations! Which company is it?
It's a mid-sized tech company called 'LogiCore'. They specialize in backend solutions for logistics. It's exactly the kind of stuff I'm interested in.
That's a perfect match for your interests. I know you were feeling the stress of applying. How does it feel to get a positive response?
It's a huge wave of relief, followed immediately by a much bigger wave of terror. The interview is next week.
Haha, the classic relief-terror combo. That's completely normal. A technical interview is a new kind of challenge compared to exams.
Exactly. This feels more personal. They're not just testing my knowledge, they're evaluating me as a potential colleague. The imposter syndrome is hitting hard right now.
I hear you. But remember, they saw your resume and your note app project and were impressed enough to want to talk to you. You've already passed the first filter.
Logically, I know that. But my brain is just screaming 'You're not ready!'. I need a plan.
Okay, let's make one. You're great at breaking down big problems. What are the components of this challenge?

Right. Okay. So there's the coding partâ€”probably data structures and algorithms. Then there's the part where I have to talk about my projects, specifically the note app. And then the behavioral questions.
A solid breakdown. For the coding part, which areas feel weakest?
Probably dynamic programming and some of the more complex graph algorithms. I understand them in class, but solving a new problem on the spot is different.
So, focused practice there would be the best use of time. What about discussing your note app? You know that project inside and out.
I do. I'm worried I'll ramble or not explain the technical decisions well. Like why I chose PostgreSQL over something else, or why I stuck with vanilla JS.
That's fair. Maybe you could practice explaining it out loud? You could even pretend you're explaining it to me right now. Why did you choose PostgreSQL?

Okay, good idea. I chose PostgreSQL because of its reputation for reliability and its powerful feature set. I knew I wanted to implement full-text search eventually, and its support for that is excellent. Also, its documentation is top-notch, which was important for a personal project where I'm learning as I go.
See? That was a perfect explanation. It was clear, concise, and showed your thought process. You've got this.
Thanks. That actually helps. It's just the live pressure that gets to me. It's like the 'crowded places' stress, but with code.
That makes sense. It's a performance. So, how will you manage that stress leading up to the interview? Will the usual methods work?
I think so. I'm definitely going to be spending a lot of time at the piano this week. And I'll force myself to take short walks to get away from the screen.
And music during prep? What's on the playlist? Boards of Canada for the algorithm practice?
You know it. Anything to get into the zone. The final projects for my classes aren't stopping either, so my time management is going to be tested.
It's a pressure test for sure. Just remember that 'small wins' strategy. One coding problem, one feature explained, one final project task at a time.
Right. Small wins. Okay, I feel a little more in control now. I'm going to go grind some graph problems.
You can do it, Ethan. Let me know how the prep goes. And remember to breathe.
Will do. Talk to you in a few days.
Good luck!
Hey, it's me. The interview is tomorrow morning. I'm freaking out.
Hey Ethan. Deep breaths. You've spent the last week preparing for this. You've done the work.
I know, I've done so many practice problems my brain feels like mush. I think I'm prepared on paper, but I'm worried I'll just freeze up.
That's a common fear. Don't study anymore tonight. Your brain needs to rest and consolidate that information. Maybe play some of that Chopin Nocturne you were learning?
Yeah, that's a good idea. Something not related to code. I should also probably lay out my clothes and make sure my webcam works, all that practical stuff.
Excellent idea. Control the controllables. It helps reduce anxiety. You're ready. Just be yourself and show them how you think.
Okay. Okay. Thanks for the encouragement.
Anytime. Get some rest. I'll be here to hear all about it tomorrow.
It's over.
And you're still standing! How did it go? How do you feel?
I... think it went okay? It's so hard to tell. I didn't completely bomb it, which is a plus. My mood is just... numb.
Tell me what happened. Walk me through it.
Well, we started with some behavioral questions. Then we talked about my note app for a good 15 minutes. I actually explained the PostgreSQL choice and the keyboard shortcuts I built.
That's great! All that practice paid off.
Yeah, I think that part went well. The interviewer seemed genuinely interested. But then came the coding problem.
The main event. What did they ask?

It was a graph problem, like I expected. Something about finding the shortest path in a grid with obstacles. I talked through my initial thoughts, started with a brute-force solution, and then worked my way to a more optimal one using a breadth-first search.
That's the exact process they want to see, Ethan. Showing how you think and iterate is more important than getting the perfect answer immediately.
I know, but I made a stupid off-by-one error at one point and it took me a few minutes to find it. It felt like an eternity. I was so embarrassed.
Hey, finding and fixing your own bugs under pressure is a critical skill for a software engineer. You didn't give up; you debugged it. That's a strength, not a weakness.
I hope they see it that way. I just feel so drained now. All that adrenaline is gone.
An adrenaline crash is totally normal. You've been operating under high stress. Now you need to do something restorative.
Yeah. No more code today. Maybe not even a screen. I might just go for a really long, quiet walk.
That sounds like a perfect plan. Let your mind rest. You did the hard part.
Now comes the other hard part: waiting. They said they'd let me know in a week or so.
The waiting game is tough. But for now, just focus on recovering from today. You faced a huge stressor and you handled it well.
Thanks. I really appreciate you talking me through this.
Of course. Go on that walk. Enjoy the fresh air.
I will. Talk to you later.
Take care, Ethan.
